content:
ASIA-PAC

Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(Aug) 1280B vs. Exp. 1300B (Prev. 1450B). (Newswires)
Chinese Aggregate Financing (CNY)(Aug) 1520B vs. Exp. 1298B (Prev. 1042B)
Chinese M2 Money Supply (Aug) Y/Y 8.2% vs. Exp. 8.5% (Prev. 8.5%)

New Zealand REINZ House Sales (Aug) Y/Y 3.1% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)
New Zealand August Median House Prices fell 0.4% M/M but rose 3.9% on a Y/Y basis.
New Zealand Fonterra said FY18 farmgate milk price at NZD 6.99/kgms and FY19 forecast at NZD 6.75/kgms; reports FY loss NZD 196mln but normalised sales revenue rose 6% Y/Y to NZD 20.4bln. (Newswires)

Indian Industrial Output (Jul) Y/Y 6.6% vs. Exp. 6.6% (Prev. 7.0%, Rev. 6.9%). (Newswires)
Indian Manufacturing Output (Jul) Y/Y 7.0% (Prev. 6.9%, Rev. 6.7%)


UK/EU

UK Brexit Secretary Raab reportedly warned that the UK will not pay divorce bill without a Brexit deal. (Telegraph)

Group of rebels in UK Conservative Party said to set a 3-week deadline for PM May to drop the Chequers plan. (Newswires)

EU is said to expect a UK shift on the Irish issue from the after the Tory party conference and have reportedly begun redrafting an Irish Brexit protocol in order to appease the UK. (Newswires)

UK PM May's spokesperson said we are focused on taking forward the Chequers Brexit plan and that the UK does not want a customs border down the Irish sea. The spokesperson added we have a commitment to no hard border and that over the course of two years the government has looked at options for the Northern Irish border and the Chequers is the only credible plan. (Newswires)

The ERG released their alternative for the Irish border in which they promised technological solutions, trusted-trader schemes and equivalence of standards on agricultural products, although there were comments from former NI Secretary Paterson that the plan provides "absolutely nothing new" while the DUP is supporting the ERG's solution to the NI-Ireland border according to ITV’s Robert Peston, who suggested it is surely chilling for a PM who rubbishes that solution and whose grip on power depends on DUP support. (Newswires/ITV)

Italy's 5 Star reportedly seeks EUR 10bln for corporate income tax or Economy Minister Tria resignation. (Newswires)

COMMODITIES

US EIA Weekly Crude Stocks w/e -5.296M vs. Exp. -0.805M (Prev. -4.302M). (Newswires)

Iran OPEC Governor said oil prices rising in favour of Russia and Saudi Arabia, while he added the US is punishing its allies and that Trump is bullying oil markets. (Platts)

NHC said although slow weakening is expected to begin by late Thursday, hurricane Florence is still forecast to be extremely dangerous when it nears the US. (Newswires)
 

US

NEC director Kudlow confirmed that US has invited China for trade talks, while there were earlier reports the US is said to propose a new round of trade talks with China in the near future with talks aimed at getting bilateral economic negotiations back on track. (Newswires)

Fed's Beige Book stated most districts noted concerns about trade tensions, particularly but not only for manufacturers. The Beige Book added that tariffs were reported to be contributing to rising input costs mainly for manufacturers and that businesses in a number of districts scaled back or postponed capital investment due to trade tensions. (Newswires)

Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dove) said further gradual interest rate increases are likely to be appropriate over the next year or two and that US economic growth is strong with the economy meeting the Fed's employment and inflation targets.  Brainard also noted that shorter-run neutral rates likely to run above the long-run in next year or two and that trade disputes are a downside risk and that trade is a source of uncertainty right now but does not see discernible impact on prices and confidence. (Newswires)

Fed's Bullard (Non-Voter, Dove) stated an inflation surge is unlikely and US interest rates are neutral to restrictive, while he expects more forecasters in 2019 to increase estimates for GDP growth to low 2% range and would consider marking up his current long-run growth forecast of 2% if growth remains above that. (Newswires)

Canada is not under pressure to get a NAFTA deal done immediately and that the most optimistic scenario is to reach a deal next week, according to sources. (Newswires)

Mexico Economy Minister Guajardo said the preliminary NAFTA agreement is written as trilateral, but also commented that we cannot rule out US and Canada not reaching an agreement and must be ready to pursue a bilateral agreement with the US. (Newswires)

US PPI Final Demand (Aug) M/M -0.1% vs. Exp. 0.2. (Newswires)
US PPI Final Demand (Aug) Y/Y 2.8% vs. Exp. 3.2% (Prev. 3.3%)
 

MARKET RECAP

Apple (AAPL) shares were still lower as it unveiled the new iPhones and iWatch devices at its Special Event; the new Apple watch Series 4 GPS model will be priced at USD 399 and the LTE model will be available for USD 499, iPhone XS with a 5.8inch display and iPhone  XS Max with a 6.6inch display; Apple (AAPL) says iPhone XR will start from USD 749; iPhone XS will start at USD 999 and iPhone XS Max will start from USD 1099. Discovery (DISCA) spent much of the session at the top of the performance table after announcing it will exclusively stream shows on Hulu, which will broaden its viewership as consumers move away from traditional TVs; the deal also includes a tie-up with Oprah’s OWN network. Tobacco names were higher after the FDA announced a clampdown on e-cigarette companies, due to teen use, helping Altria (MO), British American Tobacco (BATS) and Philip Morris (PM) to gain. Micron (MU) saw another day of losses after a downgrade at Goldman Sachs. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shrugged-off bullish commentary in its analyst presentation, as well as Oppenheimer’s bullish outlook, trading red after a downgrade at Stifel. Semis were generally mixed at the open, though some (WDC, and AMD for instance) went positive after positive news flow on China trade talks (others, like KLAC and AVGO, QCOM, could not manage to turn green). Lam Research (LRCX) was hit after a downgrade at Goldman Sachs. SPX +0.0% at 2889, NDX -0.3% at 7488, DJI +0.1% at 25998.

Yields were slightly lower at settlement, driven by a disappointing PPI report. The 10-year auction was well received, stopping through the screens by 0.5bps. Cover was a touch above recent averages, and in the breakdown, dealers took more than the previous auction. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 3+ ticks higher at 119-14.

US MARKET WRAP – 12 Sep 2018: US proposes new round of trade talks with China
content:
* SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries up, crude up, dollar down.
* REAR-VIEW: US proposes new China talks; EU’s Juncker welcomes close partnership with UK; DOE showed draw in crude stocks; OPEC MOMR cut demand estimates, reports rise in production; US PPI soft; Beige Book warns on trade; Fed’s Bullard fords not expect inflation surge.
* AHEAD: BoE, ECB and CBT Rate Decisions; US CPI and Initial Jobless Claims; French and German CPI.

* TRADE: The WSJ reported the US is said to propose a new round of trade talks with China in the near future aimed at getting bilateral economic negotiations back on track. Earlier there were reports that trade talks between the two countries may start after the November US mid-term elections. On the NAFTA front, Mexican Economy Minster Guajardo said to see a high chance of a US-Canadian trade deal, emphasizing the preliminary NAFTA agreement is written as trilateral, though he cannot rule that such an outcome will be achieved, and is ready to pursue a bilateral agreement with the US. On the Canada side, PM Trudeau reiterated his view that no deal is better than getting a bad NAFTA deal. Elsewhere, sources reported that Canada’s Foreign Minister will be returning to Washington tonight for talks, with the sources also noting that Canada is not under immediate pressure to sign a NAFTA deal, noting that there are issues that require more than a days’ work; that said, the Canadian source was optimistic a deal can be reached next week.,

* FED: Fed's Brainard (Voter, Dovish) said further gradual interest rate increases are likely to be appropriate over the next year or two noting the US economic growth is strong and that the economy is meeting the Fed's employment and inflation targets. She believes trade is a source of uncertainty right now but she does not see discernible impact on prices and confidence. Fed's Bullard (Dove, Non-voter) believes an inflation surge is unlikely and US interest rates are neutral to restrictive and there is "some room to run" in the labour market. He said to expect more forecasters in 2019 to increase estimates for GDP growth to a low 2% range and he would personally consider marking up his current long-run growth forecast of 2% if growth remains above that level.

* BEIGE BOOK: The Fed's latest Beige Book was once again noting trade concerns; most districts noted concerns about trade tensions, particularly but not only for manufacturers. Tariffs were reported to be contributing to rising input costs, mainly for manufacturers. Businesses in  a number of districts scaled back or postponed capital investment due to trade tensions. Fed says labour markets tights throughout the US with most districts reporting labour shortages. Fed says final goods and services process rising at modest-to-moderate rate in most districts though showing signs of deceleration. US economy expanded at moderate pace in recent weeks.

* BREXIT: EU's Juncker on Wednesday welcomed UK PM May's close partnership proposal and was said to agree with Chequers proposal to start a close partnership on trade, and the European Commission will not be the body to stand in the way of an orderly exit for the UK. However, Juncker once again said the EU Britain needs to understand “if you leave EU you will lose privileges”. On the UK side, PM May is said to be working to get a Brexit deal that is advantageous for the whole of the UK noting that without a Brexit deal, the position on the divorce payment to the EU changes. Also, a PM May spokesperson said a no-deal Brexit is not a likely scenario and that the focus is on taking forward the Chequers plan. He said the commitment is to have a no hard border with Ireland, noting that over the course of two years the government has looked at options for the Northern Irish border and the Chequers is the only credible plan. Later sources suggested the EU has reportedly begun redrafting an Irish Brexit protocol in order to appease the UK. Finally, former Junior Brexit Minister Steve Baker denied reports that he or any other officers of the ERG are plotting to remove UK PM May, after 50 Conservative MPs were reportedly said to oppose her Brexit plan in a meeting took place to discuss how and when they could force her to stand down. Elsewhere, sources reported that the EU has reportedly begun redrafting an Irish Brexit protocol in order to appease the UK.

* US PPI fell by 0.1% in August missing the expectations of a 0.2% rise, taking the YY headline to 2.8% below the 3.2% consensus. Core PPI also surprised to the downside and posted a 0.1% fall with Pantheon attributing the weakness to a big correction in the trade services component which makes up 23% of the measure, taking the index temporarily below trend. Also lower scrap metals and prescription drug prices added to the downside pressure. Analysts at Pantheon note it is unlikely PPI has peaked and despite data softened in the last two months, a rebound in both core goods and services is expected in September.

* SPX +0.0% at 2889, NDX -0.3% at 7488, DJI +0.1% at 25998. SECTORS: Energy +0.5%, Materials +0.0%, Industrials +0.4%, Cons Discretionary +0.2%, Cons Staples +1.3%, Healthcare +0.5%, Financials -0.9%, Tech -0.5%, Telecoms +1.4%, Utilities -0.1%.

*STOCKS SPECIFICS: Apple (AAPL) shares were still lower as it unveiled the new iPhones and iWatch devices at its Special Event; the new Apple watch Series 4 GPS model will be priced at USD 399 and the LTE model will be available for USD 499, iPhone XS with a 5.8inch display and iPhone  XS Max with a 6.6inch display; Apple (AAPL) says iPhone XR will start from USD 749; iPhone XS will start at USD 999 and iPhone XS Max will start from USD 1099. Discovery (DISCA) spent much of the session at the top of the performance table after announcing it will exclusively stream shows on Hulu, which will broaden its viewership as consumers move away from traditional TVs; the deal also includes a tie-up with Oprah’s OWN network. Tobacco names were higher after the FDA announced a clampdown on e-cigarette companies, due to teen use, helping Altria (MO), British American Tobacco (BATS) and Philip Morris (PM) to gain. Micron (MU) saw another day of losses after a downgrade at Goldman Sachs. NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) shrugged-off bullish commentary in its analyst presentation, as well as Oppenheimer’s bullish outlook, trading red after a downgrade at Stifel. Semis were generally mixed at the open, though some (WDC, and AMD for instance) went positive after positive news flow on China trade talks (others, like KLAC and AVGO, QCOM, could not manage to turn green). Lam Research (LRCX) was hit after a downgrade at Goldman Sachs.

* WTI (V8) SETTLES $1.12 HIGHER AT $70.37/BBL; BRENT (X8) SETTLES $0.68 HIGHER AT $79.74. Crude prices were supported by inventory data, weather-related fears related to the US hurricane season, as well as OPEC's MOMR report, which struck a bullish tone. Elsewhere, North Sea's Buzzard oilfield did not restart yesterday due to adverse weather. On the subject of weather, Florence is still expected to weaken on Thursday, though will still be "extremely dangerous" when it makes landfall, NHC said. The DOE reported crude stocks drew down more than anticipated (-5.3mln vs -0.805mln expected; Cushing -1.2mln vs +0.549mln expected); products, however, saw builds, with distillate stocks up more than expected (6.2mln vs 1.4mln expected) while gasoline saw a smaller than expected build (1.25mln vs 1.3mln expected). While headline crude stocks did not match the draw reported by the API on Tuesday, crude prices remained supported by the data, also taking comfort from weekly production falling to 10.9mln from 11mln. The OPEC MOMR saw downward revisions to demand estimates, but Citi's analysts were unconcerned: "The 20,000 bpd reduction in demand for 2018 and 2019 is more of a rounding error than a market-moving development, particularly since they also subtracted 64,000 bpd from their non-OPEC supply estimate for 2018," Citi said, adding that "the 278,000 bpd increase in OPEC production to 32.565 mmbpd was an added supply, of course, although already widely anticipated and still not enough to match the OPEC Q3 demand for OPEC crude oil of 33.37 mmbpd. In other words, OPEC already sees a deficit, even before a likely drop in Iranian supply."

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLES 3+ TICKS HIGHER AT 119-14 . Yields were slightly lower at settlement, driven by a disappointing PPI report. The 10-year auction was well received, stopping through the screens by 0.5bps. Cover was a touch above recent averages, and in the breakdown, dealers took more than the previous auction.

* 30-YEAR AUCTION PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 73bln in 3s (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 10s (USD 23bln on Wednesday) and 30s (USD 15bln on Thursday); with USD 24bln maturing at he month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 49bln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The Fed will allow all USD 19bn maturing at month-end (the amount is below the $24bn cap) to run off at month-end. TD Securities has noted that the US curve has steepened as of late, running "in stark contrast to Fed rate hike pricing, which rebounded following the payroll report," adding that "while the auction may see some caution given the impending September 15 tax advantage date for pension contributions, we believe long-end demand should remain robust in Q4." Focussing specifically on Thursday's auction, Barclays analysts point out that demand hs been easing at 30-year auctions, of late, with bid/cover falling to 2.27x in August, but Barclays says that demand for the long bond has still been higher this year compared to 2017. Nevertheless, performance in 2018 has been mixed, with three of this year's auctions tailing (Brclays says tails have been less volatile this year too). In terms of participation, "domestic and foreign investor participation has been consistent at the auctions this year, averaging 60% and 10% takedown each month, respectively," Barclays says, "compared with 2017, participation for both groups is marginally higher, by 1-2%."

* EUR: Ahead of Thursday's ECB meeting, the EUR was patrolling a familiar range (roughly 1.1550 and 1.1650). The ECB's meeting is expected to be a dull affair, according to most on the Street. However, that does give scope for choppy price action if there are unexpected deviations from the script, and a few analysts have raised the possibility of a dovish Draghi given trade wars, some weakening data, geopolitical concerns, as well as concerns regarding exposure to EMs. "A possible wild card would be if Draghi used these risks to express the idea that a rate hike could easily come much later than summer 2019," Credit Suisse says, "under this scenario, we would expect EURUSD support at 1.1520 to break and the pair to move into a 1.13-1.15 range." 

* GBP: Cable managed to reclaim the 1.30 handle, after losing it early doors; Lloyds notes that the pound is struggling to maintain upside momentum, despite getting back through the 1.30-1.3050 region. "A decline back through 1.2970/50 support would disappoint bulls in the near- term and suggest a range centred at 1.2900 develops as we await new news," and while it remains above 1.2825-1.2780 support, the bank says it is directionally biased toards 1.33-1.35. WA decline through this support would suggest the latest rebound towards 1.31 was merely another correction for a test of the 1.26-1.25 support region," the bank says. Other desks have suggested that the lack of upside momentum is likely due to questions hanging over whether PM May will survive beyond the Tory Party conference at the end of the month.

* CAD: The Loonie rallied to sub-1.30 on Wednesday as the positive NAFTA commentary gains traction as well as a tail wind from oil prices. Credit Suisse said that while the fundamental outlook on Canada remains solid in the light of the recent data and BoC rhetoric, it believes that positioning in USDCAD limits the potential for the loonie to rally significantly in the event of a benign outcome from NAFTA negotiations, and continues to expect the loonie to remain in a broad range vs the USD, and sees potential for CAD to further outperform the rest of the G10 commodity complex.

* JPY: Outperformed and pulling back further from 111.60+ recent peaks through expiry option strikes between 111.50-65 towards 111.25 on a combination of broad risk aversion amidst more US-China trade barbs and mainly soft US PPI metrics ahead of headline inflation data on Thursday.

* AUD: Overcame weak Aussie consumer sentiment to reclaim 0.7100+ status. Attention is on labour market data due out overnight; the data is volatile, but analysts expect it to be in keeping with an economy that is growing above its trend rates. RBC looks for a print above the trend 22k, and also is looking out for a rise in participation, which may see the jobless rate tick higher by 0.1ppts.

* ECB Monetary Policy Decision Due at 12:45BST/07:45 EDT followed by Press Conference Due At 13:30BST/08:30EDT on Thursday 13th September 2018. Unanimous expectations look for the ECB to leave its three key rates unchanged. Macroeconomic projections are set to see a minor downgrade to growth expectations. Draghi set to be grilled on trade protectionism, concerns surrounding Italy and the Bank’s reinvestment policy. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

* BoE Monetary Policy Decision due at 12:30BST/07:30EDT on Thursday 13th September 2018. The Bank of England (BoE) is widely expected to keep the Bank Rate unchanged at 0.75%, with all 71 analysts surveyed by Reuters forecasting the central bank will remain on hold. Money markets are pricing in a 0.0% chance of a hike at the upcoming meeting. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

* Central Bank of Turkey Policy Decision due at 1200BST/07:00EDT on Thursday 13th September 2018. Turkey's central bank is expected to lift its weekly repo rate to 22.00% from 17.75% (range of forecasts is between 20.00% on the low, and 25.00% on the high); anything less may than 22.00% may disappoint traders. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

AUCTION PREVIEW: US to sell USD 23bln of 10-year notes at 1800 BST/1300 EST
content:
• The US Treasury will auction USD 73bln in 3s (USD 35bln, Tuesday), 10s (USD 23bln on Wednesday) and 30s (USD 15bln on Thursday); with USD 24bln maturing at he month-end settlement, the auctions will raise a net USD 49bln in new cash, according to TD Securities. The Fed will allow all USD 19bn maturing at month-end (the amount is below the $24bn cap) to run off at month-end. 
  • Analysts at Societe Generale say the 10-year note appears to be trading rich on the curve versus off-the-runs when compared to the last two auction cycles, and argues that it is also rich versus 5s and 30s. "The 10y outright yield is near the top of this month’s range and has cheapened by more than 8bp from Thursday’s level. Any concession that brings it closer to 3% should draw in buyers," SocGen writes. 
  • "The auction may also benefit from any short covering demand from leveraged funds, which are at a record net short in TY futures," SocGen adds. On the other side of the coin, SocGen says that the increase in auction size and inflation data releases scheduled during the week pose potential headwinds for the auction.

Daily FX Wrap: several midweek humps and bumps ahead of ‘Central Bank Thursday’
content:
JPY

Emerging as the G10 outperformer and pulling back further from 111.60+ recent peaks through expiry option strikes between 111.50-65 towards 111.25 on a combination of broad risk aversion amidst more US-China trade barbs and mainly soft US PPI metrics ahead of headline inflation data on Thursday.

CAD/AUD

The next best majors, or most resilient vs the Greenback, as the Loonie continued to benefit from positive NAFTA deal expectations and largely shrugged off sub-consensus Q2 Canadian capacity utilisation to trade up towards 1.3000, while the Aud overcame weak Aussie consumer sentiment to reclaim 0.7100+ status.

NZD/CHF/EUR/GBP

All softer vs the Dollar, even though the DXY remained relatively contained within a tight 95.041-287 range, as the Kiwi struggled to advance too far from 0.6500 barriers and the Franc failed to breach resistance around 0.9700 or really strengthen beyond 1.1300 vs the single currency. Indeed, the Eur displayed some resilience vs the Usd below 1.1600 even though Italian budget support waned somewhat after reports that the Government is under pressure to raise citizen income to Eur10 bn from a reported Eur5 bn only yesterday and the 5-Star party refuted rumours it was holding Finance Minister Tria to ransom over the issue. Meanwhile, the Pound also pivoted around big figures (Cable 1.3000 and Eur/Gbp 0.8900) with positive momentum from pro-Brexit deal and Chequers White Paper remarks (to an extent) eroded as the ERG released its alternative plan to resolve the Irish border conundrum.

SCANDI

The Nok and Sek extended gains vs the Eur on more positioning ahead of tomorrow’s ECB meeting that is widely expected to underscore policy cycle divergence vs the Norges Bank and Riksbank (latter regardless of the fact that a rate hike has been pushed back). Eur/Nok down to

EM   

Contrasting fortunes for certain regional currencies, with the Lira rallying to 2 week peaks vs the Buck circa 6.3300 at one stage on last minute bets before the CBRT decides how much to tighten on Thursday, but the Forint floored by Article 7 and Eur/Huf up over 3.2600.

AHEAD

The aforementioned Central Bank meetings along with the BoE, and for previews please check the headline feed or Research Suite.

  • Apple (AAPL) – new iPhone reveal later today.

  • Gilead Sciences (GILD) – The pharma groups have announced their (FINCH 2) Phase 3 study of filgotinib results

12th September 2018

DOW JONES

  • Apple (AAPL) – AppleInsider has said the tech giant’s upcoming 2019 iPhone line-up will not have rear-side sensors as the technology is not yet ready for augmented reality advancements. This is ahead of the co.’s new iPhone reveal later today. (AppleInsider)
  • Boeing (BA) – The plane manufacturer delivered 48 Boeing 737 aircrafts in August vs. 29 in July. Note the July delivery was the lowest in years as it was impacted by supplier delays. (Newswires)
  • DowDuPoint (DWDP) – The chemical co. has announced its plans for investment in its upstream and downstream silicones franchise in attempts to accelerate innovation and meet growing demand. (Newswires)
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) – The investment bank’s incoming CEO, David Soloman, reportedly urged the co.’s whistle-blower, ex-partner James Katzman, to drop his ethic related complaints against the co. back in 2014. Katzman left the bank after nobody reviewed the complaints. (Newswires)
  • Merck (MRK) - The FDA has granted a priority review to Keytruda's application as monotherapy treatment for non-small cell lung cancer. The application is based on overall survive data from pivotal phase 3 keyonote-042 trial. (Newswires)  

S&P500

  • Allergan (AGN) – The pharma co.’s newly formed digital ventures unit, Project Moonwalker, has launched Spotlyte, a digital hub of curated content to assist consumers in how medical aesthetic treatments could fit into their routines. (Newswires)
  • Bristol-Myers (BMY) – The pharma co. has achieved its efficacy endpoints in its Phase 2 study of BMS-986165, an investigational oral, selective tyrosine kinase 2 inhibitor, in patients with moderate to severe plaque psoriasis. (Newswires)
  • Broadridge (BR) – The financial solutions co. has named Tim Gokey, currently the co.’s President and COO, to become its CEO; where current CEO Rich Daly has been appointed to Executive Chairman of the Board. (Newswires)
  • CBS (CBS) – The broadcaster has named John Martin, former Turner Broadcasting (T) CEO, and newly added CBS board member Richard Parsons as two top external candidates for the CEO role. (Newswires)
  • Citi Group (C) – The bank expects USD 2.8bln in efficiency savings by 2020 vs. its previous expectations of USD 2.5bln. (Newswires)
  • Discover Financial Services (DFS) – The Discover Bank parent has announced the launch of the Discover it Business credit card. The new card will offer unlimited 1.5% cash back on all purchases in addition to free business and security feature whilst maintaining no annual fee. (Newswires)
  • Equinix (EQIX) – The real estate co. has named Charles Meyers as President and CEO, effective immediately. Meyers will succeed Peter Van Camp, who has served as interim CEO since January 2018. (Newswires)
  • FedEx (FDX) – The shipping co. has expanded its capacity by increasing its FedEx Ground operations to six days of the week. (Newswires)
  • General Electric (GE) – The conglomerate’s jet leasing unit has drawn attention from Singapore’s sovereign wealth fund, GIC; this was made aware of in an August meeting. (Newswires)
  • Macy’s (M) – The department store is said to hire 80,000 seasonal workers in 2018 across its Macy’s and Bloomingdale’s stores, call centres, distribution centres and online fulfilment centres. (Newswires)
  • Nielsen Holdings (NLSN) – The data co. has expanded what it originally said was a strategic review of its Buy segment into what is now a broad review of strategic alternatives. Advisors include JPMorgan Securities LLC and Guggenheim Securities LLC. (Newswires)
  • Pioneer Natural Sciences (PXD), U.S. Silica Holdings (SLCA) – Energy co. PXD has entered into a long-term sand supply agreement with SLCA. In the agreement PXD have purchased an interest in SLCA’s sand reserves at its Lamesa, Texas, mine in West Texas. (Newswires)
  • Prudential (PRU) – The insurance provider has appointed Charles Lowrey, current Executive VP and COO, as CEO and new board member made effective December 1st. Current CEO John Strangfeld will retire November 30th. (Newswires)
  • Sempra Energy (SRE), British Petroleum (BP LN) – SRE, the nat. gas co., has announced its Mexican subsidiary Infraestructura Energetica Nova has signed a long-term contract with BP for the remaining 50% of initial capacity at the proposed Baja Refinados liquid fuels marine terminal in Baja California, Mexico. (Newswires)
  • Southwest Airlines (LUV) – The airline co. has reported its August preliminary traffic where it flew 11.4bln RPMs, which is up 1.3% YY, ASMs increased 2.0% YY to 13.5bln and load factor was 84.3% vs. 84.9% in August 2017. The co. has cut their Q3 capacity view to 3.5%-4% from 4.5% after citing cancellations. (Newswires)
  • Travelers Companies (TRV) – The insurer has named Mojgan Lefebvre as their new Chief Information Officer and Executive VP, who will replace Madelyn Lankton when she retires this month after a tenure of 36 years. (Newswires)
  • V.F. Corp. (VFC) - Vans Brand is targeting USD 5bln in revenue by 2023 including footwear revenue, expected to grow a 5-year compounded growth rate of 10% -12%, and apparel and accessories revenue anticipated to be above USD 1bln. Targets revenue in US regions to reach around 3bln in five years’ time. (Newswires)
  • WellCare (WCG), XL Group (XL) – The healthcare provider WCG is to replace the insurance provider XL in the S&P500 on September 17th; XL is to be acquired by AXA SA (AXA FP) on September 12th. (Newswires)
  • Wells Fargo (WFC) – The bank’s plans to repay customers who were unwillingly pushed into auto insurance have been dismissed by the OCC, US regulator, who said it needs more evidence it will do more to repay everyone who was overcharged. Elsewhere, a judge blocked a law suit made against the bank by a fund manager who was forced to liquidate his holdings in February’s volatility spike. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOGL), Facebook (FB), Twitter (TWTR), Microsoft (MSFT) – The U.S. Attorney General, Jeff Sessions, is said to be considering the opening of an investigation into social media names. This is to help determine if co.s have violated consumer or antitrust laws. Elsewhere, the EU’s executive arm has joined Google to oppose the expansion of the EU’s “right to be forgotten” outside the EU, this has implications for search engines such as Microsoft and Yahoo (VZ) and wider to social media names. The EU is also said to be proposing big fines, up to 4% of global turnover, for online names that aren’t fast enough in removing terrorist content from their websites. (Newswires)
  • Amazon (AMZN) – The online behemoth’s cloud-computing division, Amazon Web Services, has been looking to hire engineers for a planned initiative in space and satellite systems. Space could be a new frontier for the co. and its competitors Microsoft (MSFT), Alphabet (GOOGL), IBM (IBM) and Oracle (ORCL). (Newswires)
  • Celgene Corp. (CELG) – The biotech co. says OTEZLA trials showed improvements in outcomes for patients with plaque psoriasis, which may not be captured by common measures of treatment efficacy that focus exclusively on skin clearance, ie. Psoriasis Area Severity Index 75. (Newswires)
  • Gilead Sciences (GILD), Galapagos NV (GLPG) – The pharma groups have announced their (FINCH 2) Phase 3 study of filgotinib, a JAK1 inhibitor for adults with active rheumatoid arthritis, has met its primary, secondary endpoints. (Newswires)
  • Intuitive Surgical (ISRG) – The med-tech co. has had its price target raised to USD 635 from USD 575 by Wells Fargo analyst Lawrence Biegelsen. (Newswires)
  • KLA-Tencor (KLAC) – The semiconductor manufacturer has said to DigiTimes that it expects demand in China for semiconductors will see large growth. (Newswires)
  • Netflix (NFLX) – The streaming titan has seen some positive ticks on the back of Piper Jaffray analyst Michael Olson saying he sees upside in international subscribers. Citi analyst Mark May has increased his price target to USD 375 from USD 350. (Newswires)
  • PayPal (PYPL) – The online payment co. has announced that in its attempts to provide support for small businesses they have launched Fund Now, which allows businesses immediate access to completed sales. This bypasses the typical process of waiting for payments to clear; which can take up to 21 days. (Newswires)
  • Seagate Technology (STX) – The data co. is trading lower pre-market after Goldman analyst Mark Delaney lowered his price target to USD 39 from USD 44 after updating his models which now expect over-supply of NAND and DRAM. Delaney also downgraded Micron Technologies this morning (MU). (Newswires)
  • T-Mobile (TMUS), Sprint (S) – The FCC has paused its review of the merger between the two telecom providers as they need more time. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Carlyle Group (CG) – The private equity firm is said to be in talks to buy Sedgwick Claims Management Services for a value of over USD 6bln. (Newswires)
  • Carvana (CVNA) – The car financing co. has launched its as-soon-as-next-day delivery in Tulsa, Oklahoma, this doubles its presence in the state. (Newswires)
  • Energy Transfer Energy (ETE), Energy Transfer Partners (ETP) – The two energy co.s reported that ETE’s previous Registration Statement on Form S-4 for the planned merger has been declared effective by the SEC. (Newswires)
  • NXP Semiconductors (NXPI) – The semiconductor manufacturer has said in its analyst day presentation that it sees FY18-21 annualised revenue growth at 5%-7%. Following this, Oppenheimer analyst Rick Schafer has said NXPI has given a bullish outlook for medium-term growth. (Newswires)
  • RPM International (RPM) – The building materials co. has acquired the Ontario, Canada based co, Nudura Corp., North America’s leading manufacturer and distributor of insulated concrete forms. (Newswires)
  • Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) – The broadcaster has lost bargaining power against Hulu, which is jointly owned by Fox (FOXA), Comcast (CMCSA), Disney (DIS) and AT&T (T), after it refused to let the streaming service offer live CBS in many locations in the US without offering Sinclair’s the Tennis Channel. In retaliation Hulu made a deal with CBS to offer a nation-wide feed of the network. (Newswires)
  • Teva (TEVA) - The healthcare co. is delaying its launch of a generic version of Indivior's (INDV LN) opioid addiction drug amid a pending resolution of a US court case which involves Invidior and Dr Reddy's Laboratories. (Newswires)
  • Zscaler (ZS) – The cloud security co. announced its Zscaler Private Access, a zero-trust architecture, is the first to achieve Amazon (AMZN) Web Services Security Competency status. (Newswires)

subject: OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production rose 278k bpd in August to average 32.56mln bpd, according to secondary sources
content:
Crude oil output increased mostly in Libya, Iraq and Nigeria, while production declined in I.R. Iran, Venezuela and Algeria.

In 2018, oil demand growth is anticipated to increase by 1.62mln bpd, a minor downward revision from last month’s projection.

For 2019, world oil demand is forecast to grow by 1.41mln bpd, a minor downward adjustment of 20k bpd from the previous month’s assessment

Non-OPEC oil supply in 2018 is expected to grow by 2.02mln bpd, a downward revision of 64k bpd

Non-OPEC oil supply in 2019 is forecast to grow by 2.15mln bpd, a minor upward revision of 17k bpd

ASIA

Asian equity markets were lower across the board after the region failed to sustain the early momentum from US, where the Nasdaq outperformed as Apple shares were lifted ahead of its special event and with energy names boosted by a rally in oil prices. ASX 200 (flat) was subdued as losses in telecoms and financials overshadowed the upside in energy stocks and with Myer shares hit after it reported a full-year loss, while Nikkei 225 (-0.3%) slipped amid a pullback in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.3%) delved deeper into bear market territory and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) also conformed to the downbeat tone despite the PBoC’s first open market operation after a 15-session hiatus, as trade uncertainty lingered and amid Chinese commodity losses. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with trade kept in a very tight range as prices failed to benefit despite the risk averse tone and BoJ’s presence in the market in the belly to super-long end. 

PBoC injected CNY 60bln via 7-day reverse repos. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8546(Prev. 6.8488)

BREXIT

A source report noted that Brexit deal summit said to be likely by mid-November, with UK and EU preparing for meeting with leaders to sign deal and that a plan will likely be announced at September 19th-20th meeting in Austria. (Newswires)

Downing Street is reportedly drawing up secret plans and has 2 escape options if the EU rejects PM May's Chequers proposal. The first option would see Chequers parked until talks resume after Brexit day for a loosely-worded fudge on the future relationship instead. The second, is to abandon it altogether and return to a more basic Canada style free trade agreement - but only if the EU gives way on its Irish border hardline. (The Sun)

Around 50 Conservative MPs opposed to PM May's Brexit plan have met to discuss how and when they could force her to stand down. At least 48 letters of no confidence need to be submitted to 1922 Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady to trigger a vote on her premiership, and Sky sources suggest it could arrive within just a few weeks. Former Junior Brexit Minister Steve Baker denied reports that he or any other officers of the ERG were plotting to remove UK PM May. (BBC/Sky)

EU official said UK is to definitely exit the EU in March but will never be an ordinary third country for the EU, while the official added that EU’s Juncker is to say the bloc will remain firm on its divorce demands but wants a close partnership with UK post-Brexit. (Newswires)

The ERG released their alternative for the NI-Irish border, where they promised technological solutions, trusted-trader schemes and equivalence of standards on agricultural products. (Newswires)

EU's Juncker welcomes UK PM May's close partnership proposal and agrees with Chequers proposal to start a close partnership on trade. (Newswires)

EU/UK/US

Source reports suggested that the ECB had lowered their projections for economic growth, and see downside risk to growth due to weaker external demand, but keep inflation outlook unchanged. (Newswires)

The Times’ shadow MPC believes the BoE should begin paving the way for more monetary tightening this week but leave interest rates unchanged to let August’s rate increase bed in. (Times)

Canada is ready to allow US dairy access in NAFTA talks and is reportedly to offer the US limited access to the Canadian dairy market in order to try and reach an agreement, according to sources. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

BoE Governor Carney warned against complacency in the 10th anniversary of the GFC, while he outlined risks to the UK economy including high levels of household debt, no-deal Brexit, high debt for China's economy and a catastrophic cyber-attack. (BBC)

EQUITIES

Core European bourses trade mostly higher (Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%) despite the negative lead from Asia. UK’s FTSE 100 lags its peers as the index is weighed on by currency effects and weakness in utility names following a profit warning from SSE (-7.6%), dragging the sector (-1.0%) and fellow utility names such as Centrica (-3.7%) and National Grid (1.6%) in sympathy. In terms of individual movers, FTSE 100 heavyweight Rolls-Royce (-3.0%) rests near the foot of the index, while traders cite reports of an emergency landing made by an Iberian flight with Rolls-Royce XWB engines.

FX

GBP - More positive EU Brexit vibes, and this time from EC President Juncker have given Sterling another boost, with Cable back on the 1.3000 handle after a dip below on more reports about Tory plots against UK PM May, while EUR/Gbp slips back towards 0.8900 irrespective of the single currency’s rebound vs the Usd to retest 1.1600 before dipping again amidst ECB ‘source’ reports suggesting downgrades to staff GDP forecasts and downside risks to the growth outlook tomorrow.

JPY/CAD - Vying for best performer vs a flagging Greenback (DXY back down near 95.000 again vs just shy of 95.300 at best) honours with Usd/Jpy retreating to the 111.50 pivot and just under a daily chart cloud top that falls midway between decent option expiry interest from 111.50-65 (1.1 bn), while the Loonie is straddling 1.3050 against its US counterparts following reports that Canada may be willing to concede some dairy access to the US in the interests of reaching a NAFTA accord.

AUD/NZD - Narrowly mixed vs their US rival with the Aud recovering quite well from another 0.7100 downside probe given deteriorating Aussie consumer confidence overnight, and the Kiwi also keeping its head above a big figure (0.6500), albeit just.

CHF - The Franc remains relative rangebound and side-lined vs the Dollar and Euro within 0.9725-50 and 1.1305-1.1270 respective parameters, as the SNB’s next policy review comes a week after the ECB and is widely expected to maintain current policy alongside all the usual currency assessments and measures to curb excessive Chf strength/demand.

EM - Some comparative calm across the region ahead of what could well be another storm or at least volatile session on Thursday when the CBRT decides on policy and needs to deliver given aggressive/hawkish market expectations. However, reports about potential intervention from India have lifted the Rupee pre-emptively and to the benefit of others to a degree.

FIXED INCOME

Fresh peaks for bonds following dire Eurozone data and reports that the ECB staff forecasts will reflect weaker growth indicators and downside risks within the updates due alongside September’s policy meeting on Thursday. Bunds have now been as high as 159.65, +35 ticks, but not quite able to match or breach yesterday’s 159.67 Eurex session best, while Gilts extended gains to 19 ticks at 121.88 before fading ahead of resistance around 121.92. German long end supply before the 2nd of this week’s US Treasury auctions in the form of Usd23 bn 10 year notes was well received overall. In terms of upcoming data, weekly mortgage apps and PPI, while the Fed also in focus via speakers Bullard and Brainard who are both scheduled ahead of the Beige Book for this month’s FOMC. In the run-up, USTs hold a firmer and flatter line post-Tuesday’s 3 year supply.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures are taking a breather following yesterday’s rally amid hurricane concerns, the move was exacerbated by a larger than expected draw API crude inventories. Inventories showed a draw of 8.636mln barrels against the expected draw of 800k barrels. WTI futures retreated back below USD 70/bbl in recent trade. The latest from the NHC states Hurricane Florence heading towards the US East Coast and is expected to bring life-threatening storm surge and rainfall to portions of the Carolinas and mid-Atlantic states. While there are only a few refineries in Florence’s path, the hurricane poses problems in terms of cargo shipping. Laden energy cargos have not been heading towards the North/South Carolina region ahead of the hurricane. Elsewhere, gold is uneventful while copper outperforms following the recent decline in the red metal.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (7 Sep) -8.636M vs. Exp. -0.800M (Prev. -1.200M). (Newswires)

Wednesday’s domestic docket is bereft of any scheduled releases or events, so breaking Brexit headlines will continue to dominate barring anything major on the global front. content: The 10 year German benchmark is grinding higher after a relatively tame initial mark up and brief dip from yesterday’s 159.30 Eurex close, and on top of moderately firmer US Treasury leads, the obvious supportive factor is weakness in Italian BTPs, or more precisely a partial retracement following recent heady gains. 12th September 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets were lower across the board after the region failed to sustain the early momentum from US, where the Nasdaq outperformed as Apple shares were lifted ahead of its special event and with energy names boosted by a rally in oil prices. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was subdued as losses in telecoms and financials overshadowed the upside in energy stocks and with Myer shares hit after it reported a full-year loss, while Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) slipped amid a pullback in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) delved deeper into bear market territory and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) also conformed to the downbeat tone despite the PBoC’s first open market operation after a 15-session hiatus, as trade uncertainty lingered and amid Chinese commodity losses.

FTSE

Sky (SKY LN) – The GBP 26bln battle for Sky is to be decided by a sealed bids auction contest by 21st Century Fox (FOXA) and Comcast (CMCSA) unless there is a best-and-final offer for Sky by the end of next week. The auction will be administered by the Takeover Panel. (FT) A sealed-bid auction is a type of auction process in which all bidders simultaneously submit sealed bids to the auctioneer, so that no bidder knows how much the other auction participants have bid. The highest bidder is usually declared the winner of the bidding process.

UK/EU

A source report noted that Brexit deal summit said to be likely by mid-November, with UK and EU preparing for meeting with leaders to sign deal and that a plan will likely be announced at September 19th-20th meeting in Austria. (Newswires)

Downing Street is reportedly drawing up secret plans and has 2 escape options if the EU rejects PM May's Chequers proposal. The first option would see Chequers parked until talks resume after Brexit day for a loosely-worded fudge on the future relationship instead. The second, is to abandon it altogether and return to a more basic Canada style free trade agreement - but only if the EU gives way on its Irish border hardline. (The Sun)

Around 50 Conservative MPs opposed to PM May's Brexit plan have met to discuss how and when they could force her to stand down. At least 48 letters of no confidence need to be submitted to 1922 Committee chairman Sir Graham Brady to trigger a vote on her premiership, and Sky sources suggest it could arrive within just a few weeks. (BBC/Sky)

EU official said UK is to definitely exit the EU in March but will never be an ordinary third country for the EU, while the official added that EU’s Juncker is to say the bloc will remain firm on its divorce demands but wants a close partnership with UK post-Brexit. (Newswires)

BoE Governor Carney warned against complacency in the 10th anniversary of the GFC, while he outlined risks to the UK economy including high levels of household debt, no-deal Brexit, high debt for China's economy and a catastrophic cyber-attack. (BBC)

The Times shadow MPC believes the BoE should begin paving the way for more monetary tightening this week but leave interest rates unchanged to let August’s rate increase bed in. (Times)


FX

In FX markets, the greenback was mixed against its major counterparts with EUR/USD back below 1.1600 and as GBP/USD approached 1.3000 to the downside after the recent fluctuations triggered by a deluge of Brexit-related headlines. Elsewhere, USD/JPY pulled-back amid the risk averse tone and AUD/USD gave up the 0.7100 handle after weakness in metals prices and disappointing Consumer Confidence data, while CAD was boosted by source reports Canada is prepared to allow US dairy access in NAFTA talks.

Australian Westpac Consumer Confidence Index (Sep) 100.5 (Prev. 103.6). (Newswires)
Australian Westpac Consumer Confidence (Sep) M/M -3.0% (Prev. -2.3%)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with WTI crude futures firmer after prices gained 3.5% the prior day and briefly broke above USD 70.00/bbl amid US hurricane and Iran related uncertainty, with upside further exacerbated by a significantly larger than expected draw in headline API crude inventories. Elsewhere, the metals complex was less inspiring as gold retreated and copper traded subdued amid weakness in Chinese commodity prices.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (7 Sep) -8.636M vs. Exp. -0.800M (Prev. -1.200M). (Newswires)

Russia Energy Minister Novak said the oil market remains fragile on output decline in some countries including Venezuela and that he sees oil market impacted by geopolitics such as Iran-related uncertainty. Furthermore, Novak commented that they will discuss oil markets with OPEC this month in Algeria and will make decision on what more to do, while he also stated countries have potential to raise oil output. (Newswires)

EIA cut 2018 world oil demand growth forecast by 80k BPD and now sees 1.58mln BPD YY rise, while it reduced 2018 crude output estimate to 10.66mln BPD (prev. 10.68mln BPD) and lowered 2019 world oil demand growth view by 100k BPD to 1.47mln BPD YY rise. (Newswires)

NHC said Florence is forecast to be an extremely dangerous major hurricane through landfall which is expected to bring a life-threatening storm surge and rainfall to the Carolinas and mid-Atlantic states. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

US, North Korea and South Korea mull October for the 2nd summit between US President Trump and North Korean Leader Kim. (Nikkei)
 

US

The short end was sold seeing yields on 2s and 3s rise to fresh decade highs. There was some talk of short covering cited, as well as concession heading into this week’s supply. In early trade, there were reports of a large 5s30s flattener going through, but by settlement, the spread was unchanged, while other curve spreads were biased towards extremely modest widening. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 9+ ticks lower at 119-10+.

US President Trump commented that trade talks are going well and Canada wants to make a deal with both sides operating in good faith. Trump also stated it would be good if US makes a deal with Canada but would be ok if it doesn't, and that the US is taking a very tough stance with China on trade. (Newswires)

Canada is ready to allow US dairy access in NAFTA talks and is reportedly to offer the US limited access to the Canadian dairy market in order to try and reach an agreement, according to sources. (Newswires)

Canada PM Trudeau said there is a good NAFTA deal to be had but reiterated no deal is better than a bad deal and stated US auto tariffs would also impact the US. (Newswires)

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks declined across the board as region failed to sustain Wall St momentum
content: Asia equity markets were lower across the board after the region failed to sustain the early momentum from US, where the Nasdaq outperformed as Apple shares were lifted ahead of its special event and with energy names boosted by a rally in oil prices. ASX 200 (-0.1%) was subdued as losses in telecoms and financials overshadowed the upside in energy stocks and with Myer shares hit after it reported a full-year loss, while Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) slipped amid a pullback in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.4%) delved deeper into bear market territory and Shanghai Comp. (-0.3%) also conformed to the downbeat tone despite the PBoC’s first open market operation after a 15-session hiatus, as trade uncertainty lingered and amid Chinese commodity losses. Finally, 10yr JGBs were flat with trade kept in a very tight range as prices failed to benefit despite the risk averse tone and BoJ’s presence in the market in the belly to super-long end.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks trade in the red after failing to sustain Wall St momentum
content:
Asia equity markets are lower across the board after the region failed to sustain the early momentum from US, where the Nasdaq outperformed as Apple shares were lifted ahead of its special event and with energy names boosted by a rally in oil prices. ASX 200 (-0.1%) is negative as losses in telecoms and financials overshadowed the upside in energy stocks and with Myer taking a considerable hit after it posted a FY loss, while Nikkei 225 (-0.4%) slipped amid a pullback in USD/JPY. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) delves deeper into bear market territory and Shanghai Comp. (-0.2%) also conforms to the downbeat tone despite the PBoC’s first open market operation after a 15-session hiatus, as trade uncertainty lingers and amid Chinese commodity losses.

In FX markets, the greenback is mixed against its major counterparts with EUR/USD back below 1.1600 and with GBP/USD approaching 1.3000 to the downside after the recent fluctuations triggered by a deluge of Brexit-related headlines. Elsewhere, USD/JPY pulled-back amid the risk averse tone and AUD/USD gave up the 0.7100 handle after weakness in metals prices and disappointing Consumer Confidence data, while CAD was boosted by source reports Canada is prepared to allow US dairy access in NAFTA talks.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are flat with trade kept in a very tight range as prices failed to benefit despite the risk averse tone and BoJ presence in the market in the belly to super-long end.
